Bayes formula written two ways in latex
\[
P({A } |
{ B}) =
\frac{P({B}
| { A})
\times
P({A})}{P({B})}
\]
\[
P(\textrm{A } |
\textrm{ B}) =
\frac{P(\textrm{B }
| \textrm{ A})
\times
P(\textrm{A})}{P(\textrm{B})}
\]



Here is a footnote 1. I can type before
and after the footnote.



Here are a few quotes from the show Ted Lasso

“Taking on a challenge is a lot like riding a horse, isn’t it? If you’re comfortable while you’re doing it, you’re probably doing it wrong.”  The best we can do is keep asking for help and accepting it when you can. And if you keep on doing that, you’ll always be moving towards better.

The first quote was said by Ted Lasso while the last quote was said by the character named Higgins.



Here are some pictures of my dog Roxie. She is 14 years old.
   



Here is a funny video on YouTube:




Basic mermaid diagram with code found here2




flowchart LR
  A[Hard edge] --> B(Round edge)
  B --> C{Decision}
  C --> D[Result one]
  C --> E[Result two]





here is a mermaid diagram that I altered myself - I only went a couple layers deep




flowchart LR
 A(Plate Appearance in Baseball)
 A --> B{Pitch is thrown}
 B --> C{Strike}
 B --> D{Ball}
 B --> E(Ball in Play)
 C --> C1{Strike}
 C --> D1{Ball}
 C --> E1(Ball in Play)
 D --> C2{Strike}
 D --> D2{Ball}
 D --> E2(Ball in Play)
 C1 --> C3(Strikeout)
 C1 --> D3{Ball}
 C1 --> E3(Ball in Play)
 C1 --> F{Foul Ball}
 D1 --> C4(Strike)
 D1 --> D4{Ball}
 D1 --> E4(Ball in Play)
 C2 --> C5{Strike}
 C2 --> D5{Ball}
 C2 --> E5(Ball in Play)
 D2 --> C6{Strike}
 D2 --> D6{Ball}
 D2 --> E6(Ball in Play)








Berrar (2018) says ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem ipsum lorem

title: Slides
text:
Python Code Cell
Code:
#| echo: true
#| code-fold: true
#| code-summary: "expand for full code"
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
df = sns.load_dataset("penguins")
sns.set_theme(style = 'white', palette = 'Pastel1')
FS = 18
g = sns.jointplot(data = df, x = "flipper_length_mm", y= "bill_length_mm", hue = "species", s = 150)
g.ax_joint.set_xlabel("Penguin flipper length (mm)", fontsize = FS)
g.ax_joint.set_ylabel("Penguin bill length (mm)", fontsize = FS)
g.ax_joint.tick_params(axis = "both", which = "major", labelsize = FS)
plt.savefig('plot_2.pdf', bbox_inches = "tight")


Code
import seaborn as sns
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
df = sns.load_dataset("penguins")
sns.set_theme(style = 'white', palette = 'Pastel1')
FS = 18
g = sns.jointplot(data = df, x = "flipper_length_mm", y= "bill_length_mm", hue = "species", s = 150)
g.ax_joint.set_xlabel("Penguin flipper length (mm)", fontsize = FS)
g.ax_joint.set_ylabel("Penguin bill length (mm)", fontsize = FS)
g.ax_joint.tick_params(axis = "both", which = "major", labelsize = FS)
plt.savefig('plot_2.pdf', bbox_inches = "tight")









Berrar, Daniel. 2018. “Bayes’ Theorem and Naive Bayes Classifier.” Encyclopedia of Bioinformatics and Computational Biology: ABC of Bioinformatics 403: 412.
